title: Can SEO be a career? - Quora

response.answer_text: Some Good Reasons to Choose SEO as Your Career 1High demand for SEO services Once SEO was not a separate profession – Web masters performed some basic SEO for the sites they managed and that was all. But as sites began to grow and make money, it became more reasonable to hire a dedicated SEO specialist than to have the Web master do it. The demand for good SEO experts is high and is constantly on the rise. 2A LOT of people have made a successful SEO career There are many living proofs that SEO is a viable business. The list is too long to be quoted here but some of the names include Jeff from Theseowhiz, Jill Wahlen from High Rankings, Rand Fishkin from SEO Moz and many others. 3Search Engine Optimizers make Good Money ! SEO is a profession that can be practiced while working for a company or as a solo practitioner. There are many jobboards like Dice and Craigslist that publish SEO job advertisements. It is worth noting that the compensation for SEO employees is equal to or even higher than that of developers, designers and marketers. Salaries over $80K per annum are not an exception for SEO jobs. As a solo SEO practitioner you can make even more money. Almost all freelance sites have sections for SEO services and offers for $50 an hour or more are quite common. If you are still not confident that you can work on your own, you can start a SEO job, learn a bit and then start your own company. If you already feel confident that you know a lot about SEO, you can take this quiz and see how you score. Well, don't get depressed if you didn't pass – here is a great checklist that will teach you a lot, even if you are already familiar with SEO. 4Only Web–Designing MAY NOT be enough Many companies offer turn–key solutions that include Web design, Web development AND SEO optimization. In fact, many clients expect that when they hire somebody to make their site, the site will be SEO friendly, so if you are good both as a designer and a SEO expert, you will be a truely valuable professional. On the other hand, many other companies are dealing with SEO only because they feel that this way they can concentrate their efforts on their major strentgh – SEO, so you can consider this possibility as well. 5Logical step ahead if you come from marketing or advertising The Web has changed the way companies do business, so to some extent today's marketers and advertisers need to have at least some SEO knowledge if they want to be successful. SEO is also a great career for linguists. 6Lots of Learning For somebody who comes from design, development or web administration, SEO might look not technical enough and you might feel that you will downgrade if you move to SEO. Don't worry so much – you can learn a LOT from SEO, so if you are a talented techie, you are not downgrading but you are actually upgrading your skills packages. 7SEO is already recognized as a career Finally, if you need some more proof that SEO is a great career, have a look at the available SEO courses and exams for SEO practitioners. Well, they might not be a CISCO certification but still they help to institutionalize the SEO profession. Some Ugly Aspects of SEO 1Dependent on search engines It is true that in any career there are many things that are outside of your control but for SEO this is a rule number one. Search engines frequently change their algorithms and what is worse – these changes are not made public, so even the greatest SEO gurus admit that they make a lot of educated guesses about how things work. It is very discouraging to make everything perfect and then to learn that due to a change in the algorithm, your sites dropped 100 positions down. But the worst part is that you need to communicate this to clients, who are not satisfied with their sinking ratings. 2No fixed rules Probably this will change over time but for now the rule is that there are no rules – or at least not written ones. You can work very hard, follow everything that looks like a rule and still success is not coming. Currently you can't even rely on bringing a search engine to court because of the damages they have done to your business because search engines are not obliged to rank high sites that have made efforts to get optimized. 3Rapid changes in rankings But even if you somehow manage to get to the top for a particular keyword, keeping the position requires constant efforts. Well, many other businesses are like that, so this is hardly a reason to complain – except when an angry customer starts shouting at you that this week their ratings are sinking and of course this is all your fault. 4SEO requires Patience The SEO professional and customers both need to understand that SEO takes constant effort and time. It could take months to move ahead in the ratings, or to build tens of links. Additionally, if you stop optimizing for some time, most likely you will experience a considerable drop in ratings. You need lots of motivation and patience not to give up when things are not going your way. 5Black hat SEO Black hat SEO is probably one of the biggest concerns for the would–be SEO practitioner. Fraud and unfair competition are present in any industry and those who are good and ethical suffer from this but black hat SEO is still pretty widespread. It is true that search engines penalize black hat practices but still black hat SEO is a major concern for the industry. So, let's hope that by telling you about the pros and cons of choosing SEO as your career we have helped you make an informed decision about your future. Source: http://www.webconfs.com/seo-career-article-23.php

response.answer_text: Most definitely. There’s a few routes you can go with working in SEO as a search engine optimizer. It’s become a skill that’s increasingly in-demand over the years because many business owners realize they need to have an online presence in some shape or form. Even if their brick-and-mortar business caters to a local region, having the site optimized for SEO can increase sales. In fact, research showed that 72% of people who did a local search visited a store that was less than 5 miles from their location—28% of those people would even go on to buy something! Some of the skills you’ll need to be a top SEO include: Coding - you don’t need to be a programming whiz by any means. Basic HTML and CSS skills will be enough, but you need to know how to look at a website’s source code and make sense of it.Writing - content is king, as they say. Being able to produce quality content can be the difference in your site getting found and the content being lost in the ether. Writing for the web is a particularly specific skill - learning how to keep people’s attention is key.Research - SEO is all about how to get your content found on search engines. Knowing what types of keywords people punch into Google and why they’re searching for these terms helps you pivot and create a solid content strategy.Analysis - research and analysis go hand in hand. After generating the data, you need to know how to make sense of it. What is their behavior when interacting with your site? How long are people spending on pages? How many pages do they visit before leaving? Which ones attract the most attention?If you’re seriously thinking about becoming an SEO, you can become a salaried employee (usually working in the marketing department), a freelancer, or using those skills in your own business. The average salary for an SEO is $50k according to Glassdoor. This will fluctuate depending on where you work and your experience, but that doesn’t factor in the employee benefits. You’ll at least have job security and a steady stream of income each month. As a freelancer, you’ll have more room to maneuver and you can take on different projects for as many or as few clients as you want. This gives you more flexibility since you have control over your hours and workload. However, your income is determined by how much work you can find at this time, and whether clients are willing to pay you at your desired rate. Freelancing can often be heavily influenced by your network and relationships with previous clients. You can search on job boards but it might not yield the results you want. Lastly, there’s starting up your own business. You don’t have to drop everything and put all your eggs in this basket. In fact, many entrepreneurs work on a side business outside of their 9–5 job during evenings and weekends, slowly sowing into a blog or content site and adding content/optimizing the site to rank higher on Google. Once you’ve got enough content on there, you can start applying for display ad networks like Google Adsense or affiliate programs (if your site has product reviews and it makes sense to include these links). After some time, roughly a year or so later, this project can yield so nice results and give you another stream of monthly income. It’s not unusual for content sites to provide ~$2k-$4k each month in net profit. And the great thing about content sites is once you’ve done all the hard work at the beginning to get it off the ground, you can actually work fewer hours on it since traffic will continue trickling through. As long as your content is evergreen and your niche community is active, people will visit your site. Alternatively, if you have the skills but not the time to start up a business, you can buy a content site. This can really save you a lot of hours and sweat equity because you’ve already got a profitable business in a niche that’s earning money through a solid business model. If you’re interested in what content sites that sell for 6-figures looks like, check out our marketplace here - Online Businesses For Sale on the Empire Marketplace

Work NatureUnlike other careers, where uncertainty & compliance are limited and manageable, SEO is a highly result-oriented career where uncertainty & compliance play a lot of role. Although, it is not a complex subject it is often considered to be toughest because it requires an SEO person to think analytically, relating things with one another, observe behavior patterns, investigate issues, solving complex problems, create workarounds, find out trends and implement the best practices. Also, as SEO evolves quickly it is often considered to be one of the most challenging careers. 2. PayAlthough it is not a high paid job when compared to the tech jobs, you'll still be able to make a decent salary in SEO career. It is difficult to mention ranges because it depends on several factors like industry, location, work experience etc. But on the whole, if you gain a good work experience of at least 2 years with a few achievements on your resume, you can expect a good compensation. 3. Regarding SEO, I can tell you that an SEO guy is one the happiest persons on the planet because the work is challenging in nature and you'll experience the taste of success when you achieve something with lot of persistent effort and dedication. Trust me on this, I've been the most happiest guy for the past 7 years of my SEO career. response.answer_text: It is, but maybe not in the way you'd think.SEO is a wide field these days with multiple branching paths. I'd also add that SEO isn't really a singular career; it's increasingly rare to find someone that does purely optimization work or link building, so you should think of it as more of an area of specialization in a broader marketing career. A lot of SEOs start off as search analysts, link builders, content writers, social media marketers or web designers. The outcome for many is to advance into a director or VP of search role, take a wider role in inbound or content marketing, or start their own agency. Some of the more technically minded SEOs get into product management or start marketing software companies. It's wide open. Check out the Moz 2014 Industry Survey - it covers the breadth, depth, and diversity of paths pretty well. Why do so many people think they can make a career out of this?For one, there's a lot of hiring demand for both in-house and agency SEM/SEOs and there is lots of work to go around, so one could make a career for themselves as a corporate marketer, freelancer, consultant. Refer to:SEM Research - SEMPO: SEMPO Salary SurveySEMPO State of Search Industry ReportAlso, there aren't really any barriers to entry - you don't need a specific degree or a license to call yourself an SEO. The basics are easy to pick up, but the learning curve steepens quickly once you start working on complex projects or in competitive markets. This makes for a rather wide knowledge gap between a good and average SEO so it is becoming harder to find, hire, and retain good search talent.

response.answer_text: SEO is a career, and a lucrative one. The fact is that right now, companies are tripping over themselves to optimize their web presence over that of their competition. Given that SEO is a somewhat labor intensive, specialized skill, market demand for it is insane at this point. And given that SEO looks like magic to the average business owner, the money is considerable - if you can deliver the results. The beauty is that there is no barrier to entry for SEO services, so anyone can do it. The downside is that there is no barrier to entry, so anyone can do it. Competition in the SEO market is savage. It isn’t based upon any formal schooling degree, but based upon the results you can deliver to a company. This means that you can’t fake your way through it. Posers are quickly sniffed out, and cast aside. However, anyone can become proficient. There are many resources out there for anyone interested to tap in to, and luckily, MOST people while work at it for a while, and then give up or lose interest. So if you can give it a legitimate go, you’re already going to be way ahead of your competition. Advice: If you’re considering getting into SEO as a career path, it’s easy enough to develop your skills immediately. 1. Tap into the vast archive of SEO information available online. You can find enough free information out there to get a great start. 2. Offer to do SEO for a friend or family member, and track the metrics. See how it goes, see how you like it. Are you beginning to understand the interconnectivity of the SEO process? 3. When you get good enough at it, and can show provable results, offer your services locally to small/mid-sized businesses. This is where you start, because those are the people who need it most, and that’s where you can have the most impact. 4. The more you can refine and perfect your skills, the more you can charge, the more clients you will take on, and the more successful your SEO career will become.

The world of SEO is always changing, and it’s something businesses and brands will always need. If one can master this art and change with the times, it’s definitely a skill that is highly in demand. From a training and learning perspective, if you want to increase your site traffic, SEO and content promotion is the best way to accomplish it. SEO is all about the content you create and how you promote it. Without the necessary promotion, your website or blog will just get lost in the mix. No matter what niche market you are in, it’s extremely important to know your audience and what type of content they want. This will help with SEO and ranking for long tail keywords that your audience is likely typing into Google. Also make sure you niche down as much as possible, as this is where you are going to find opportunity and be able to potentially establish your site as an authority and trusted resource for information. If you want to improve your site’s SEO and make your content better than what’s currently out there, it’s all about the content creation and content promotion plans you have for your site. These are the two most important things to remember. CONTENT CREATION - Only create great content that provides real value and is better than what’s currently already out there. Google your competition, see what type of content they have, then create something better and be sure to include stats and visuals when possible. CONTENT PROMOTION - With over a billion active websites and blogs online, there is already way too much content out there. Without the necessary content promotion, your site is just going to get lost in the mix. You need to continually promote your content to new audiences. To better explain all of the above and how you can use such methods to increase traffic on your own site let’s cover the many components that go into a great marketing and branding plan to grow a website or blog. Not only will content creation come into play, it’s also how much effort you put into your content promotion as well. In the world of blogging, this can be done in a number of ways. We are currently using the following methods to increase traffic, backlinks and exposure to our sites: High quality blog content, case studies and tutorialsSocial media to connect with new audiences and share blog contentThe creation of shareable content like infographicsGuest blogging and article contributions on other sitesCreating expert round ups of other top bloggers and industry influencersGetting interviewed on other podcasts and running a podcast of our ownIf you implement these tips into your own marketing and content creation efforts you should see continued success.

response.answer_text: To add to great answers already posited: SEO quite simply is the act of increasing sales in the online marketplace. I'm oversimplifying, of course, due to the nature of the question, but essentially SEO involves a set of best practices and strategies that help businesses augment their visibility on the Internet.  As for the 2nd part of the question regarding the possibility of a person making a living from SEO work, the easy answer is yes. Most of the other answers so far address SEO from a freelance or entrepreneurial standpoint, explaining that the market is saturated and full of unsavory characters all vying for same business. In this way, it can be difficult to make a living, since there are always "black hat" SEOs promising unrealistic results by essentially spamming google. Unfortunately, many of these phony hacks blindside local business owners out of hard earned cash, only to damage the company's online presence with bad linkbuilding techniques which break Google's terms of service and lead to a penalty that can completely remove that business from the search results page.  I am lucky enough to work for a large, enterprise level search marketing company (8th largest in terms of ad spend) that services many Fortune 500 clients. For me, it isn't just possible to make money from SEO, my entire livelihood depends on it. And right now, I'm making a pretty decent living from it-- more than I have from any of my other marketing jobs. If you have a good deal of diverse experience, a person can easily make upwards of 80k a year working for a large SEM company.  Hope that answers your question!

response.answer_text: My opinion, is that a career in SEO will always be in demand in some way. Sure, SEO has changed over the years, but without a doubt, search rankings will be integral to the marketing strategies of online businesses for years to come. The industry will make (and has made) changes over time, but I can’t think any scenario where SEO will no longer be important. It is important to know however that SEO is one piece of the much larger digital marketing ‘puzzle’, and that SEO in itself is a puzzle made up of many individual pieces. Career wise, this gives opportunities for several positions - Digital Marketer, SEO Specialist, SEO Consultant, SEO Content Writer, Technical SEO specialist, and on and on. Furthermore, you have several options of positioning yourself, career-wise, if you are able to get a strong grasp on executing solid SEO techniques. You could work for a digital marketing agency, become a SEO freelancer (using sites like Upwork, PeoplePerHour, Guru), or even start your own agency. Certainly, with a strong SEO skill set, there will be many opportunities both now and in the future. If you’re looking at the freelancer/agency route, check out this article — The Secrets to Successfully Starting an SEO Company | CanIRank. It will definitely give you some insight on the present industry and the outlook on the industry in the future; and also offers some great professional tips to working with SEO clients and working with a successful SEO process. No matter which career path you choose, I wish you the best of luck!

What is called "SEO" is really just a collection of best practices. To be successful in "digital marketing," you need to be well-rounded -- you need to know website development in a search-engine context well, social media well, content creation well, website analytics well, online PR well, online advertising well, conversion optimization well, and a lot more. In short -- you need to have a desire to learn all the time! Conversely, some people pick one of those items and become well-renowned experts in that specific issue. For example, a global expert in everything analytics can sometimes do better than a digital-marketing generalist. There are good and bad sides to each approach.

Great question. I’d argue (and have argued elsewhere) that SEO isn’t actually a thing. Or rather, it’s a combination of things. So while you can find jobs as “an SEO”, you can’t be effective at it without pretty wide-ranging digital marketing knowledge. You’ll need to work in social, content, and web development without a doubt. And it’ll be beneficial to have experience in digital advertising, email/marketing automation, and event marketing/sponsorship. SEO is all of those things. At the very least, it should have its hands in all of them. To be a truly effective SEO, you need to think about every single customer touch point and how they can be massaged to boost website rankings. A company’s website is its face and marketplace on the web. Organic search is free traffic, like people wandering into brick-and-mortar stores off the street. If all you concern yourself with is link building and on-page optimizations, you’re only doing 10% of what you could be doing to get more of that sweet, sweet organic traffic.
